properties.areaDesc: Wabash, IL; Knox, IN; Gibson, IN
properties.headline: Flood Warning issued January 8 at 12:00PM EST by NWS Indianapolis IN
properties.description:
...A Flood Warning continues for portions of the following waterway
in Indiana...

White River...


.As of late Wednesday morning, lowland flooding was coming
to an end at Hazleton on the lower White River in southwest Indiana.
This will bring flooding to a close in the Indianapolis National
Weather Service area of responsibility for the time being.

A strong storm system will bring moisture into Indiana from both the
Gulf of Mexico and Pacific as the week wraps up.  This setup is
expected to bring copious rainfall to the state Thursday afternoon
through Saturday morning, with the heaviest rainfall coming late
Friday through Friday night.  As of late Wednesday morning, rainfall
totals by Saturday evening are predicted to total 2.50 to 3.50
inches in much of central and southern Indiana.  Today's river
forecasts capture a portion of the expected rainfall associated with
the incoming system.  A much better idea of how high the rivers will
likely go will come with Thursday's forecast model run.

The Flood Warning continues for
The White River at Hazleton.
* until further notice.
* There have been no observations in the last 24 hours.
* Flood stage is 16.0 feet.
* Minor flooding is forecast.
* Forecast...It is forecast to crest at 19.8 feet Friday January 17
and will rise above flood stage by late Sunday night.
* At 20.0 feet...Most of the low bottomlands flood. Flooding begins in
higher bottomlands. High water affects any residents in Pottsville
river cabins. Pottsville Road...North C Street on river side of
railroad tracks and Catt Street near U. S. Highway 41 are flooded.
Water is near or starting on Giro Road in the vicinity of submerged
Pottsville Road. Oil stripped fields flood. Flood gates must be
installed at Hazleton.
properties.instruction:
Precautionary/Preparedness Actions...

Motorists should never drive into flood water. Turn around and go
another way. Keep children away from flooded areas. Recreational and
agricultural interests should remain alert to changing river
conditions.

For detailed flood information go to weather.gov/ind on the web and
click on rivers and lakes.
